posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i, Talya aka rassilon1963, hold the following statements about Signal to be self-evident, and not requiring further examination.

1. you don’t have the data (and neither do i).

Signal doesn’t collect usage statistics. there’s also many forks and unofficial packages of Signal. as such nobody can claim to know anything about Signal users as a collective. statements such as “most Signal users have/don’t have a linked device”, “most Signal users use/don’t use stories” etc. can be dismissed outright.
remember: the plural of anecdote isn’t data. just because you and your contacts do something one way doesn’t mean anything in the context of all Signal users.

2. there’s many visions for Signal, and those visions are contradictory.

for any belief about how Signal should behave there’s an equal and opposite belief.
Stories are one of the most controversial features Signal ever adopted. they’re also one of the most requested features. SMS removal and the 2021 colour changes were argued over for years and had 4 digits of comments each, and the argument may have continued to this day had the moderators not (justifiedly) locked the topics so they stop wasting everyone’s time.
the only way to make absolutely everyone satisfied is to make every single choice a toggle, and end up with a settings page the length of the Odyssey.

3. features don’t correspond to adoption.

features are good. but they’re not a good determiner of app adoption. just because a feature should be adopted doesn’t mean that hoards of people are being pushed off the app because it is missing.
people don’t use apps because of their features. they do so because of their values and because of the network effect. if features were a good determiner of adoption, WhatsApp wouldn’t be the most popular messenger on the planet.
also, remember point 1: you don’t have the data to show a lack of feature prevents app adoption, and i don’t have the data to show the contrary.

4. there’s no timeline, and that’s a good thing.

Signal doesn’t have a public roadmap, a fact that is quite famous in this forum. but even when a feature is in active development, Signal usually doesn’t give a time frame - and that’s a good thing, because releases always get delayed. Usernames were first projected to be released in early 2023 - their actual release was in February 2024. looking at other projects, the COSMIC desktop environment was projected to have two alphas before the beta release - they ended up having seven.
promising a timeline is a good way to get people disappointed, or to rush stuff out before it’s ready.

5. there’s never gonna be a less secure version of Signal.

call it what you want, be it the “light version”, the “normie” version, whatever, it’s not going to exist. there’s not gonna be a “dual security mode”, you’re not gonna have the option to choose your own encryption algorithm, and you’re definitely not gonna have “plaintext but only in this very specific context”. if you subpoena Signal and ask for all the info they have on a phone number, all they can tell you is when they registered and when they last connected to the server, and they’ll fight tooth and nail to keep it that way. as such any request that is reliant on Signal having more data on you is dead on the spot.

6. don’t try and argue for a security theatre.

if a “security feature” can be easily circumvented, it should either be reframed to be something other than a security feature, or abandoned.
take disappearing messages for example. since they were first adopted in 2016, the message was very clear: “Disappearing messages are a way for you and your friends to keep your message history tidy, not for situations where your contact is your adversary.”
if your security feature can be circumvented then it’s not a security feature. and if it’s not a security feature, then it better be useful in some other way, otherwise it’s just there for the show and should not be in the app.

7. don’t chat with adversaries.

even the best app in the world can’t save you from chatting with an adversary. if Alice is a political dissident and Bob is secretly a cop, there’s nothing Signal can do to guarantee Alice doesn’t share incriminating information with Bob. if Bob is an ally but he has malware on his phone, there’s nothing Signal can do to guarantee Alice doesn’t leak incriminating information via Bob.
Signal can and should try its best. in fact, it often does. but it can’t save you from trusting someone who isn’t trustworthy.

you are welcome to concur or add other self-evident statements below.

posts.cooked:
i’m not sure is it totally for the list, but somewhat related.

sometimes it is more important to secure underlying operating system than getting perfect communication program.

let’s take friends devices out of the question now, and we cannot directly control their devices anyway.

if i have two scenarios, a: getting perfect communiaction program but not so good operating system, b: communication program could be lacking, but underlying operating system is perfect and secure.

i may take scenario b quite often. of course this depends on use case and possible threat model. some people seems to think that installing signal (or another good program), then everything is secured. but it is some kind of operational security, how you use devices and programs. some kind of overall context is required for devices and communication programs.

rassilon1963:

features are good. but they’re not a good determiner of app adoption. just because a feature should be adopted doesn’t mean that hoards of people are being pushed off the app because it is missing.

I think that this one is a bit more nuanced. While Whatsapp owes its user base to the network effect features are a way to consolidate and make it harder for people to move away from it. Take for example communities: Signal does not have something comparable, so if you are a member of a club/group that uses this feature you’re out of luck if you propose migrating to Signal.

I do realise that adopting Signal and replacing Whatsapp are two different things, but I also think that something more is needed than just adoption: we need a significant number of people to shift to Signal as their primary (and preferably only) messaging app.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
as i’ve said in that point, features are good, but the point is they’re very rarely the reason people opt for a certain product. the jump in Signal adoption in the EU that happened last year wasn’t because Signal added a feature or because WhatsApp removed one.
again, features are good. but when people choose to move to another app, they do it because of their values (q.v. the WhatsApp ToS fiasco from a few years ago) or because they have people they can only reach on a certain app.
for certain demographics of people i’d even say Signal is more well-featured than WhatsApp. but that’s not leading to more adoption.
this is not an anti-feature point. it’s just that features should be judged on their own merits, and not because they’re allegedly “the reason more people don’t adopt Signal” because a. that’s not the case and b. even if it were one wouldn’t have the data to confidently claim that.

I think an even more nuanced view would have it that features don’t matter any more, because Signal now has pretty much feature parity with other messenger apps.

Back when e.g. we had Groups v1, the incomplete and unhelpful way in which groups operated was actually a factor in putting people off - I for example could not even get myself to recommend Signal to my friends until groups v2, because I knew as soon as we would hit one of groups v1’s “particularities” it would be game over, possibly forever.

So features, I believe, do matter in that sense.

With back-ups in beta I think that the biggest risk that people could be ticked off about (data loss) has been addressed.

While I agree that the necessary feature parity is mostly in place I don’t think that Signal can afford to offer significantly worse UX than the dominant competitor in a given market. I think it’s very naive to assume that all user growth is due to people’s values, because typically somebody making that decision will ask their contacts to sign up as well. I don’t think that the latter group will put up with a significantly degraded experience compared to what they’re used to.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
fair enough. i definitely agree we can divide features into basic architectural stuff, high-point-of-tension features and nice-to-haves (one could come up with better names for these). i don’t recommend Matrix to people for example because to me it’s lacking in the basic architectural level - there’s security issues, unsolveable spam issues, [unable to decrypt] issues etc.
features in the first tier can definitely stop adoption because they introduce a ton of friction that can be visible very early on and make users give up very quickly.
tier two features may cause some users to abandon the app, but it’s less likely and it’s not gonna be all of them. there’s probably a small correlation between them and adoption that one can see if one has data.
tier three have no correlation though, or at least not a meaningful one. the number of users for whom it’s a dealbreaker is negligible.
and the thing with Signal (hence why these truisms are relevant to the forum but not necessarily outside it) is we’re pretty much out of tier 1 & 2 features. PNP was, i’d argue, the last tier 1 feature remaining to knock. backups are probably the last tier 2 feature, and even if they’re not, there’s probably not many left.
and tier 3 don’t have to be small features - stories were a huge thing, but they’re also very much a tier 3 thing. i highly doubt a non-negligible number of users abandoned Signal because they weren’t there, but I’m still glad we have stories.
same for other features i advocate for. Signal is now mature enough that the last “adoption blocker” i believe in (lack of phone number privacy) is gone.

Perhaps we also need to define “adoption” a bit better. Is that 1) using Signal to chat with Alice because she asked you, or is it 2) preferentially using Signal alongside a big competitor, even with people who use the same big competitor, or is it 3) using Signal exclusively?

Most of my contacts are number 1 (with me being Alice). Everyone else I know, including even myself and my immediate family, are number 2 because otherwise I would not be able to communicate with virtually everyone from work and other projects I work on.

rassilon1963:

because of the network effect.

Currently IMHO this is the biggest barrier. And, actually, the reason why this year I may be able to get lots of work colleagues into Signal from WA is features - PNP in particular, which WA doesn’t do (yet?).

posts.name: Thomas Isaksen
posts.cooked:
DonDino:

And, actually, the reason why this year I may be able to get lots of work colleagues into Signal from WA is features - PNP in particular, which WA doesn’t do (yet?).

I would ask, what does PNP stand for?

Because you’ve touched the idea of moving your peers to Signal, I just want to share my experience, on the same topic.

At one point, I made an attempt to shift the casual conversations of my colleagues from WhatsApp to Signal. Aside from the more formal communication that flows through Microsoft Teams, we’d long maintained a WhatsApp group for lighter, more relaxed exchanges. The advantage, of course, was that while not everyone was willing to install Teams on their personal devices, nearly everyone already had WhatsApp installed and in constant use.

I gently broached the idea of moving to Signal, but two things became immediately clear:

  1. Despite the fact that many of my colleagues are fairly tech-savvy, the majority didn’t see the need for a new app. WhatsApp, they argued, sufficed for their needs. Some even went as far as to ask, “What do you want to hide? They already know everything about you.”

  2. The suggestion of installing yet another app was met with apathy, perhaps even resistance. The one they were already using worked well enough, and that comfort was difficult to shake.

From this, I’ve come to the conclusion that Signal, in the eyes of my peers and acquaintances, is seen as a kind of digital fortress, an app reserved for those who must hide from authority, be it the government or their employer. As for the everyday, mundane exchanges we all have, they’ll continue to thrive in the apps already embedded in our lives, immovable and set in stone.

To truly break this network effect, I believe Signal will need more than just its privacy-centric appeal. It will need a defining feature, or that killer feature as some might say, something unique, something that elevates the experience in a way no other app has managed to do. Something that taps into the everyday needs and desires people have, something that could convince them that it’s worth the switch, or at least worth trying out. Maybe it’s a unique way of organizing communication, a way of enriching the experience that no one else has yet thought of.

posts.cooked:
Thomas.Isaksen:

It will need a defining feature, or that killer feature as some might say, something unique, something that elevates the experience in a way no other app has managed to do.

sigh…

rassilon1963:

people don’t use apps because of their features. they do so because of their values and because of the network effect.

everything you’ve said in your comment is a perfect demonstration of the network effect. they don’t say WhatsApp’s E2EE is for criminals - because they don’t care. they use the app because everyone uses the app.
Signal already has a killer feature no other app has - you can use it without revealing your phone number. it also has a bunch of features WhatsApp doesn’t have, and a better UI.
and there’s other chat apps that have wayyyy more features than WhatsApp. but they don’t have two billion users.
because say it with me:

rassilon1963:

features don’t correspond to adoption.

I do mostly agree with this.

rassilon1963:

features don’t correspond to adoption.

We have an organisation that has different types of internal and semi-public chats. Most of these are on WhatsApp because it is convenient for people.

“We already have it, and everyone else does to.” Is the usual argument against switching.

There is also a corresponding, semi-separate, national level organisation, also using WhatsApp and it’s a circular argument of “local branches are on WhatsApp, so we are too” and “the national branch is on WhatsApp, so we are too”…

However, I do believe that features (specifically polls and pinned messages) are one of the stronger arguments against switching as well, i.e. I have managed to convince some internal people to use Signal, but only for chats that don’t normally use these features.

So, while I do agree that the network effect is absolutely the strongest component, in specific cases (especially organisations) features are also a deal-breaker for some.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
if features were the determining factor those people would be on Slack, Discord or Telegram, or Matrix, not WhatsApp.
Features don’t correspond to adoption.

I do agree that they don’t correspond to self-driven adoption (i.e. the adoption waves you mentioned after some WhatsApp crisis or other), but for convincing people to adopt, I think they do.

Yes, the “default” that was chosen at some point was WhatsApp because of it being common, but when trying to convince people to switch, features do matter. If I were trying to convince people to use Slack, Discord, Telegram or Matrix, it would be easier, because the polls feature is there. I might actually try to convince them of Matrix next, exactly because of this, just trying to figure out, where to host. :)

I think the difference here is exactly the “global vs. local” argument you mentioned. Just because it helps locally, doesn’t mean it corresponds to global adoption. But it can still be helpful locally nonetheless.
